Dialogue.NPCText:
The air in this catacomb seems to writhe and squirm. A lean, pale man in a grimy hooded shroud stands amid cages, chains, and a swarm of docile rats. His eyes glint with morbid delight as you approach.

"Welcome to the Undermarket, friend. I am Ilyas the Ratsmith—extractor of secrets, collector of debts, and occasional connoisseur of pain.
Did you come for information... or to see what secrets you yourself might spill?"

Option.text: I’m looking for work, not trouble.
Those rats... are they your friends?
Tell me more about your... hobbies.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ilyas grins, flashing stained teeth. "Oh, you’ll find both down here, eventually. But I do have a job for someone with courage and a disregard for personal safety.

A traitor—my former apprentice, Jaedon the Silver-Tongue—hides in the tunnels beneath the Arena. He carries secrets meant for my ears alone, but now he trades them to Qasaria’s enemies... perhaps even to Minax herself.
Track down Jaedon, silence him, and bring me proof: the locket he stole from my kit of tools. Do this, and you may learn things Omar al-Onyx would kill to keep hidden."

Option.text: How did you fall out with Trinsic?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"The Undermarket is Qasaria’s hidden pulse. Down here, you’ll find things you’d never see in those golden streets above—spells forbidden, secrets for sale, poisons, and pleasures both rare and wretched.
Zahid is king in these tunnels, but the Council of Jewels all send their shadows to buy or sell what the sun would wither. If you need to know who is plotting against whom, you come to me or my rats."

Option.text: On second thought, do you need help?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Jaedon was clever, slippery as oil. I taught him every method of extracting truth—from the rack to the whisper. But greed gnawed at him. He began selling what he learned: passwords, blackmail, the names of spies.
He hides now among the arena’s slaves and gladiators, trading pain for gold. You’ll know him by the rat-shaped scar on his left hand—and the silver locket, a gift he stole as he fled. Bring it to me, and you’ll be paid in coin... and secrets."

Option.text: What does this have to do with Omar al-Onyx?

Dialogue.NPCText: Ilyas lowers his voice. "Omar thinks himself untouchable atop his arena. But Jaedon knows the names of every fighter Omar has paid with Minax’s black coin. Bring me that locket, and I’ll tell you what I know—names that could shake Qasaria’s foundations."

Option.text: So Omar is working with Minax?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Minax’s shadows reach everywhere, especially where gold flows thick and easy. Omar may not know all his own debts, but Jaedon does. Some of those debts are paid in blood, some in souls. Qasaria will fall if Minax’s rot spreads deeper.
Help me cut out the gangrenous limb, and perhaps the city will survive."

Option.text: I’ll find Jaedon and bring you the locket.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ilyas’s eyes gleam. "Good. The tunnels beneath the arena are a maze—full of desperate men, lost beasts, and worse. Trust no one. When you have Jaedon’s locket, return to me. Payment awaits—if you make it back alive."

"Trinsic lost its taste for unpleasant truths. After the Paladins took over, inquisitors like me became... inconvenient. Too many questions, too many skeletons. I took my tools and left for somewhere a little more honest—Qasaria’s shadows."

"Here, secrets pay better than virtue. In a city run by merchant-princes and warlords, there’s always a buyer for what I can supply—pain, silence, or a whispered warning. Besides, the food’s better than in Trinsic."

"Zahid rules the Undermarket with a velvet fist. I trust him as much as a snake trusts another snake. We share business, not friendship. But he keeps order down here, and that’s good for rats like me."

"Everyone thinks they run the Undermarket. Zahid’s the biggest spider, but there are others: Council agents, foreign spies, even priests looking for lost relics. The real power is information—and no one hoards more than my rats."

Option.text: Do you need a hand with anything?

Dialogue.NPCText: "Pity. You looked like you had the stomach for it. If you change your mind, the tunnels will still be there—and so will Jaedon. And so will I."

Option.text: On second thought, I’ll take the job.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ilyas licks his teeth and chuckles, a sound like dripping tar.

"Ahh... finally, someone asks the right question. Torture, secrets, and rats? No, no, those are just tools. What I truly enjoy is watching the soul unravel, thread by thread. Would you like a glimpse of what that means?"

Option.text: Only if it doesn't involve my own thread...
That sounds vile. I should go.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ilyas laughs, though there’s no mirth in it.

"Worry not, friend. I don't harm without cause. I'm no butcher—I’m an artist. Each scream a stanza, each confession a brushstroke. My magnum opus? A paladin who begged to forget his name. Took three weeks."
He leans in. "But you... you strike me as someone who's seen things too. What’s your vice?"

Option.text: I like gold. Everything else is noise.
I crave knowledge, even the dark kind.
Honestly? I enjoy hurting the right people.
Never mind. This was a mistake.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Ilyas pulls out a thin hooked blade and balances it on his finger.

"There’s truth buried in pain, like gold in a corpse’s mouth. But if you’re not ready to taste it, I can offer a... gentler initiation."
He snaps his fingers and a rat climbs onto your boot, staring at you with unsettling stillness.

Option.text: What... what do you want it to do?

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Ah yes, the oldest wound of all—avarice." Ilyas claps softly.

"Many bleed for faith, but most bleed for coin. You’ll do well down here. Just don’t ask where your next paycheck comes from."
He flicks a small coin at you.

You feel dirtier… but richer.

Ilyas’s eyes gleam. "Then you’re in the right place. The deepest truths are buried under floorboards, behind locked memories… and sometimes, in someone else’s mouth."

Your mind sharpens ever so slightly.

"Oh... how delightful," Ilyas says, eyes narrowing.

"Righteous violence, selfish violence—does it matter? The end is the same: someone broken, someone made whole. You may not be so different from me."
A black rat slinks up beside you. It hisses approvingly.

Ilyas whispers: "Speak your true name aloud. If the rat doesn't bite, you’ve nothing to fear."

You hesitate. The rat’s teeth glint in the torchlight…

The rat sniffs... and scurries away.

Ilyas grins. "Well now. Either you're honest—or you lie better than most. Either way... impressive."
You feel your Fame shift in the shadows.

Option.text: You’re creepy, but I like you.
